war ' than this. . . . LXXXV. The Celtiberiam, after making a truce

with the consul M. Claudius Marcellus, had sent ambassadors to Rome who remained there quietly waiting for the answer of the senate. Meanwhile M. Claudius went on an expedition against the Lusitani, took Nercobrica by assault, and then went into winter quarters at Corduba. Of the ambassadors who came to Rome the senate admitted those from the Belli and 'I'itthi,l who were favourable to Rome, to enter the city ; but ordered those from the Arevacae2 to lodge on the other side of the Tiber, as being at war with Rome, til] such time as the senate should have decided the whole question. When the time for the interview was come, the praetors introduced the envoys from their allies first.
